translated: Jātaka
The Collection of Eight 🔽The Chapter on Kaccāna
The Kaccāni Jātaka
“Wearing white, pure, with wet hair,
Kaccāni, why are you sitting by the pot of honey?
You’re washing sesame seeds and rice,
saying, ‘Sesame porridge, why not?’”
“This isn’t for eating, brahmin,
saying, ‘Sesame porridge, why not?’ is well-cooked.
The Teaching has died, and now there’s much alcohol.
I’ll make it in the middle of the charnel ground.”
“Investigate and do what needs doing, Kaccāni.

original: Dhammo mato ko nu taveva saṁsi;
analyzed: dhammaḥ mataḥ kaḥ nu tava iva sasi
translated: The Teaching has died. Who else but you?
The one with a thousand eyes, of incomparable power,
The best of the Teaching will never die.”
“I’m very sure of this, brahmin,

analyzed: dhammaḥ mataḥ na atthi mama ittha kaṅkhā
translated: The Teaching has died. I have no doubt about this.

analyzed: ye iye iva dāni pāpāḥ bhavanti
translated: Those who are now wicked
are now happy.

original: Suṇisā hi mayhaṁ vañjhā ahosi,🔽Sā maṁ vadhitvāna vijāyi puttaṁ;
analyzed: su nisā hi mayham vañjhā ahosi  sā mam vadhitvāna vijāyi putta
translated: My barren wife🔽killed me and gave birth to a son.
She’s now the ruler of the whole family,
while I’m cast out alone.”

analyzed: jīvāmi vā ūham na mata ūham asmi
translated: “I am alive, not dead,

analyzed: tava iva atthāya idha āgataḥ asmi
translated: I have come here for your sake.
I will reduce to ashes the woman who killed you and gave birth to a son,
Together with her son.”
“If this pleases you, King of the Gods,

analyzed: mama eva atthāya idha āgataḥ asi
translated: You have come here for my sake.

analyzed: aham ca putto suṇisā ca nattā
translated: I, my son, my daughter-in-law, and my grandson,
Let us live in harmony in the house.”
“If this pleases you, Kātiyānī,

analyzed: hatā api santā na jahāsi dhamma
translated: Even though killed, you do not abandon the Dhamma.

analyzed: tuvam ca puttaḥ suṇisā ca nattā
translated: You, your son, your daughter-in-law, and your grandson,
Let us live in harmony in the house.”
The daughter-in-law and Kātiyānī,
Living in harmony in the house,
The son and grandson served them,
Honored by the King of the Gods.”
The Kaccānijātaka is the first.
